ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lectures and in-person lab, but also virtual lab for some.
live virtual lectures + virtual breakout room groups sessions/advising + virtual meetings + in person meetings

in- person discussion format
live virtual lecture
A mix between virtual lecture, virtual discussion, virtual lab and in person lab.
Virtual lecture and lab, with an option to use lab spaces for design and build work.
Live Virtual lectures in combination with in-person/virtual group project work.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to write reports, i guess?
CAdesign, mechanical analysis, project pitches, construction of a business case, working with a team, knowledge of safety in engineering and practices in the industry
Design experience and project management
I felt this course was less about learning and more about applying knowledge from the past three years into an engineering project.
How to work in a team as an engineer.
Hands-on, practical experience in the engineering process, from determining a problem, brainstorming and prototyping solutions, and working on implementation.
Understanding of the engineering design process, specifically with regards to initial research and defining requirements.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: High expectations, but this is probably related to the changes due to the pandemic. Being understanding and flexible was great, but it would be even greater if the standards were realistic from the start.

Weaknesses: it was a lot of work. feedback on expectations could be given more promptly
strengths: the groups were put together in a thoughtful way, advising was available whenever we needed and more, accommodations were made to ensure that we could work on our projects in real life

Lectures are not super helpful, especially if you've taken other engineering design classes. I was very excited for this class, but the reported expectations were apparently not always the teaching staff's actual expectations, and the work was easily twice that of a regular class if not more. Clear, reasonable expectations and a way to more evenly divide work between team members would help. We are all already overworked and sleep deprived, and honestly I've lost all faith in teamwork. From what I found talking with other teams, every group had team dynamic and work distribution problems, some more than others, and the only way I can think to change this is to make individual's grades more reflective of their own personal effort. Teamwork could be a huge strength for this class, but some structural issues need to be improved so people prioritize and are excited about the projects as a group.

I loved being able to pick our projects this year!!! But I felt the selection of groups could have been done more in line with people with similar interests over just who Prof Booth thought should be in a group together. I liked the virtual lectures, and thought the balance between those and group work time was well done.

A strength of the course is that it gives us a lot of trust and freedom to choose our topic and guide our design process how we see is best for our project, with guidance from the teaching staff, who is very available for conversations and questions throughout the course. A weakness is a lack of direction and actionable feedback. Particularly with the last design review, we did not have much time for questions or comments, and we were unable to get much meaningful feedback from fellow students or teaching staff from the presentation.

Strengths: students are able to and given the resources to pick and develop the project of their choosing. The instructors are very available for help and feedback

Weaknesses: Lectures feel as if they are just there to pass a requirement rather than as a learning experience. The assignment requirements are confusedly written and require constant questions to the instructors
Overall I think the class is structured well given the circumstances.  I think the challenge of the disconnect between lecture material and group work was exacerbated by the virtual format.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: more in person availability of the engineering lab would be super helpful.
This course is not suited for a virtual format and really suffered because of it.

I think the teaching staff did as much as they could. Obviously, it was not ideal to have senior design over zoom, but my project group was able to work together in the CEID and in Becton, and the teaching staff was very supportive and attentive to our needs.

The instructors did quite a good job of distributing materials and opening lab space whenever possible.  The limitations were handled well.  Virtual lectures are challenging, as they are for all courses, but are perhaps made worse by the feeling that time for the class should be spent on project work, making lectures feel disconnected.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you need to take it, you need to take it.

Ask yourself the following questions: Am I an ABET Mechanical Engineering major? and Do I still want to be? 
If your answer is yes to both then yeah take this class.
A good project and good team is key, if you don't have both it is pretty draining.

If you are taking this course, you are taking it for ABET senior design. That being said, I think the teaching staff have done a lot to improve the course over the past few years and by allowing students to pick projects that they are excited about, I think I have definitely enjoyed the class more than students in past years have.
You gotta do it for ABET.
It's a requirement for the MENG major, but honestly it's also a decent introduction to design practice and methodologies.
